DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Little Changed in Quiet Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were little changed in quiet early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as export optimism offset selling linked to warmer temperatures in the nation's midsection. Trading was light, which is typical for a holiday period. The markets opened mostly lower, extending the weaker pattern established Tuesday due to warmer temperatures in the Great Plains and Midwest after a two-week cold spell. But selling pressure waned and buying interest surfaced early in the session, partly reflecting the Agriculture Department's weekly grain-inspections report, which showed unexpectedly large exports of corn, wheat and soybeans last week. Some buying also stemmed from Spain's overnight purchase of 180,000 metric tons of U.S. corn and from expectations that Pakistan will tender tonight for 26,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean oil, said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.10 a bushel; corn futures were unchanged across the board with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $1.52 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to } cent lower with January at $5.68\ a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly lower while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .07 cent to .28 cent lower with February at 77.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent lower to .10 cent higher with January at 85.10 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February at 49.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .27 cent lower to .03 cent higher with February at 49.50 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled higher on Tuesday.
